title: Catch 'em all (v2 - remixed!)-3
description: Have spent too many hours on this today and it definitely leaves me frustrated and thinking about the experiences of students and teachers in classrooms. Currently I'm teaching in a classroom with both desktops and laptops (different models, every kid has a slightly different one), and I've run into all kinds of bugs like these, which definitely make the process of learning to code harder!
instructions: UGH. Press the green flag to get a sense of things. I remixed a previous project so that everything falling was part of the scrolling, but ran into a TON of bugs. It works great offline; breaks differently in Chrome (can't move left/right) than it does in Firefox (where the background turns pink and giant for some reason). Debugging encouraged! (It seems like all the sprites work fine, but there's something about the way the background is blown up that Scratch hates? But also, it worked fine in the previous iteration?

title: The "See You At MIT!" Pass-It-On Project
description: For Day 20 of Getting Unstuck, I decide to revisit the "3 Favorite Things" pass-it-on project from Day 11! I loved learning about the Getting Unstuck community. I also loved that day because people remixed the project to make it better, making each element standalone (using "when sprite clicked") instead of sequential (using "broadcast and wait"). I'm starting this new pass-it-on project in this way that scales better. I hope you'll join in! And I hope to see you in person this week! ❤️✨
instructions: Click on me to find out why I'm excited about the MIT Scratch Conference, which is taking place this week! Then add yourself to this pass-it-on project!

title: Truffle's Idea Tumbler
description:
updates on this iteration for Day 20:
I made a few detail edits, such as adding in spaces between the responses that Truffle joins as an idea. Sometimes when trying something new, the details are missed, and I'm glad to come back to this! I also added a feature where you can add a question to Truffle's memory. What question might bring some playful ideas?

original notes:
AHHHHH - This was my first time exploring strings and lists!
^---- that's a very excited ahhhh!

At first I wasn't even sure what the string blocks might be used for. I started off by looking at the Scratch wiki (https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/String) to see what they even did. (thanks @paulinah)! Then I thought that I would create something that generated randomized text. 

The most exciting part of creating this came as I was thinking of questions to ask. As I plugged in Ask " " and wait, and "add answer to list" at least 15 times, and saw my code grow longer and longer, I wondered how I could randomize the questions so that they might appear in another order (or be repeated, for re-considering other potential responses.) I thought, if I could put them somewhere and ask for a random one, that would be great. I had just created my first list of the answers to questions. It was a sparkly realization moment when I thought "what if I stored the *questions* in a list, too??? This way, they could both be randomized when called upon and ALSO be more organized, not making my script forever long. I was honestly feeling kind of unsure about taking on lists -- and there I was, creating lists on lists to be joined in (lovingly) weird strings! I'm excited to see where this new discovery goes!

During the recent Getting Unstuck project on changing scenes, I decided to try a "pause and come back" strategy in stuck moments. When I paused, I'd go in the vector editor and work on this cat face, thinking I'd surely use it for something in the future. I felt comfortable enough to play around with creating the cat while also thinking through the challenges in the project I was programming. For this challenge, I didn't spend ANY time on drawing, as I'd already created the cat. I wonder how far I would've gotten in the lists + strings exploration if I were also focusing on creating my own graphics?
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar to start.

Once Truffle has started sharing potential ideas, click on her and she'll share more (:

(update: press up arrow to add a question to Truffle's memory!)

title: Visual Editor, Improved
description:
This project was originally created for Day 14 for Getting Unstuck, and then revised for Day 20 of Getting Unstuck. I had originally set out to make a multiline text editing box, maybe even with a scroll bar. Wow, that was harder than I thought it would be. So on Day 14, I settled for the ability to enter characters.  

For Day 20, I added support for the Delete and Enter keys. Again, this was much harder than I thought it would be; it actually makes use of an undocumented Scratch feature, described here: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19199766/.  After concluding that there would probably not be an IPO for "Visual Editor, Improved", I decided that the only thing left to do before abandoning ship was to add a cool Easter egg. Enjoy!
instructions:
Press the green flag and enter a brief message in the text box. Only lowercase, unaccented characters and space key accepted for now.  The delete key can be used to fix mistakes; press enter when done. 

Easter egg: What happens when you type a few words but forget to press enter for a few seconds?

description:
Unstuck day 20
This is derivative of a project I began on day 13 and revised on days 14-15.  I've experimented with: connecting it to makeymakey instruments, bending notes based on the cursor's y position, separating graphix from sound, creating feedback loops through the user's microphone, and with eliminating a need for a user.

In this edition I changed the primary graphic to a spinning ball of thread. Given further time, I'd like to gamify this by creating an additional sprite that one tries to "catch" or grab with the fingertip. I think it will be necessary to use the timer and reset blocks to establish whether one has caught the other sprite (to distinguish it from a coincidental on stage passing-by).

An exciting discovery from this project has been the ability to use phantom sprites (e.g., no costume) to shadow other sprites, often by looping a glide instruction e.g. to the x/y of the first sprite. At this phase of iteration I may not be using any phantom sprites in a significant way, but - as we near the conclusion of GU - that's the grist on my mill. Another breakthrough from days 13-15 for me was that I could make these graphix without requiring the user to click or press down on the mouse/trackpad. The gentle fingertip and trackpad activity feels like a new Scratch experience. I'm very grateful for these discoveries! Thanks for the provocations!

Followup: made a remix for PicoBoard so the instrument can be set by a force resistant sensor connected to port D https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237255829/
instructions: Green flag. Move fingertip on touchscreen to change note.

title: Unstuck Day 20: Remix of Making Music
description:
For my Getting Unstuck challenge Day 20 I decided to add more features to my earlier music playing project. I got stuck big time on what seems to be a bug in Scratch. If a variable is displaying below a Y position of 0 you can't get the options you should get when you right click on it. I finally figured out you only get those options if you move it above 0. Big headache!
The trickiest part of adding all these features was design. It was hard to think of ways to give the user enough information. I still think some lines on the bars would make it better to show the increments you can differentiate by.
instructions:
Pick notes to play in a rhythm on the BLUE bar, then click PLAY.
Play along with your rhythm loop on the LIVE bar.
You can change both instruments on the RHYTHM and SOLO bars.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Getting Random Improved
description:
I realized today I missed day 6 which was all about random, so I started to create, and iterated on the fly - I'm calling this day 6 and day 20 as I've spent far longer than usual on the challenge and have made big improvements on my original idea! 

I spent lots of time tweaking how you know as the user if for example two random costumes are the same (so used a changing backdrop to let you know the costume had changed) and also how you can be sure you've clicked one of the sprites below.

Enjoy!
instructions:
Here's a project to test your memory.  When you click the green flag, you'll see the sprite with the box around it change costumes.

Once it's finished, click the sprites at the bottom of the screen in the same order that the main sprite changed. Press space bar to see if you got it right, and to advance.

title: Getting Unstuck day 20
description: For today I added to yesterday's project. I wanted to add a power up that would make it possible to eliminate some of the dealy tacos. I thought about have the cat shoot lightning bolts at the tacos, but that brought up all the complications of aiming and so on. Then I hit on just having a shield that destroyed the tacos if they touch it. At first I made the force field a costume the cat has. That did not work, i guess because the tacos had contradictory instructions. So I made the force field a sprite that always goes to the cat, but is hidden unless the shield is recharged and the user presses <space> before getting hit with a taco.
instructions:
green flag to start
arrow keys to move
space key for a 2 second force field that destroys tacos 

careful- the force field has to recharge before you can use it again

title: Unstuck 20 Clone Rabbits Jumping
description:
I wanted to complete the following behaviours I didn't have time to include before. Happy with the result. 
- clones run both left and right
- clones disappear as they near the left and right edge of screen (first time using the ghost effect).
I experimented with multiple "When I start as a clone" blocks. Love this.
If I had more time, I would like to make the hopping effect more realistic by making sure when rabbit lands, he changes costume immediately before traveling along the x-axis. I probably should have NOT using multiple "When I start as a clone" blocks in order to make it look better. Oh well, the short and simple was good enough for today.
instructions:
Choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck and revise it.

The Rabbit will give you instructions.

title: day 20 revision and revisiting
description: I started learning about Kolam designs. I had never really thought about how graph paper traditionally has the dots in a 90 degree relationship and how if the dots were in a 60 degree relationship - everything would be so different!! This made me wonder about making 90 degree and 60 degree patterns in the same file online. I think I used the clones to track where I was, but I'm still really unsure about what clones are and how they work... and how I might have coded exactly this same result without using clones and most importantly the pros and cons to using clones here!!!! Please help me understand this!!??
instructions: Click the green flag to start and see if you can imagine how to make another shape flower

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 20 — Reactive Rainbow
description:
Reflection

I decided to make a couple of changes to my Day 13 project. I really liked the effect of the colors chasing the mouse, but overall the project needed a few extra tweaks to give it a more finished feel.

The changes I made are: The dots are now smaller. I added the use of the mosaic effect. And the dots are now created in a grid formation rather than randomly.

Even though the changes are minimal, the overall look and feel of the project has improved significantly.
instructions: Move the mouse pointer of the red dots.

title: Cat on a desert island copy
description:
This is an improved version of the stranded cat. Now with CLOUD VARIABLES.

Cloud variables are very interesting. The most easy thing to do with CV are records tables and halls of fame, but they can be used to do a lot of things, like multiplayer (if you have a good connection).
I have the feeling that is one of the interesting features that I used the less (besides creating plug-ins for the offline version).

Sounds on freesound.org:
rainfall by sonitusetaudio
thunders by juskiddink, Yoyodaman234 and olliehahn12
instructions:
Show and modify variable "hour" to see the different states of this scene.

The starting position should reflect the time of the day. The cat goes to bed at 22 o'clock and gets up at 7 in the morning. Some days are rainy!

Every time someone visits the island (in a single day), a fruit will appear!

description:
It works!
Fix-ups: Repeated motion across screen prevented the broadcast from switching to the next command because the previous instruction was not complete. (Thank you @paulinah for your feedback and advice!) There were too many types of event block command (green flag, space bar, when __ broadcast, when backdrop changes) – messy.  Stages weren't changing on cue.  .  Changed “broadcast and wait” (in Stage coding) to “broadcast” (and not wait) on sprite pages.  Hide/show sprites changed to "broadcast . . . " instead of "when backdrop changes to . . . "

title: Slinky Remix Unstuck #20
description: I thought this would be quick and easy - ha! I spent hours remixing this, but I'm really happy with how it turned out. In the original project I defined a block called "circle", the sprite drew the circle, moved a little, and made another circle. It was a cool design, but I wanted it to look more like a real slinky.  I ended up almost completely remaking the entire project. In the end I made the sprite the actual circle and stamped it. The code is pretty simple, so it doesn't look like I spent hours on it, but I kept trying different things and then tweaking it until I came up with this.
instructions: Click the green flag to begin

title: Day 20 remix Day 17
description: Thank you kfugle for your advice.  I remixed this and created a script for each color with lots of broadcast/receive blocks for all the combinations of right and wrong conditions.  Took a lot of thought and errors, but I think it finally works.  Boy did my code grow!  Along with my skills :-)

title: Get Smart enhanced_GU_Day20
description:
Day20 changes include: addition of background music, additional backdrops (including psychedelic flowers as a clue for the final puzzle), only one question per mission, & tightened up some code.
Original comments: This project took on a life of its own. I didn't get stuck today. Oh, wait, I spoke too soon. When running my project to check it, sometimes the sprite with the intro words becomes very large & off the screen. (Is this b/c I have both bitmap & vector graphics running at the same time?) 
Since the project is multi-faceted, it took a very long time to accomplish.There is so much more that can be done to enhance it. 
Inspiration for the Q & A came from @karenb 's project with the escape room.

title: Tag Day20: Getting Unstuck Day 13 copy
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

The idea of interacting with the mouse led me to the idea of tag. I don't know if my project really fulfills the brief, but I enjoyed making it.
If I were to continue working on it, I would introduce a few other elements, such as making the reaction of "running away" sprites dependent on their distance to "it." 
In addition, I would have the characters call out "You're it!" or "I'm it!" when they were tagged.
So, I've worked a bit more on making my sprites a bit more individual in their strategies. In addition, I made Scratch Cat's speed more like that of the other sprites.
instructions: Press the green flag. Play tag as Scratch Cat.

title: Getting Unstuck #20
description:
For day 20 I decided to rethink day 7. I wan't overjoyed with my day 7 project. And I thought rather than trying to make something that ended with a static result, something that constantly moved may be more interesting.
I included some of the cloning ideas that I worked with yesterday. I'm happier with this than day 7's project. I could still tinker with this for ages if I had the time.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Day 9 revisited
description:
I didn't know what to revisit. I spent ages going between projects. I went through the getting unstuck cards and played with some featured projects. When I returned to my getting unstuck studio I saw my "robot line follower" from day 9 and knew it was the one from the notes I'd written about what I'd like to try with more time. I'd never normally write notes like that, so I think I will try to in future to capture my thoughts at the time rather than allowing them to drift away. 

I have been thinking about line following robots. Seemed like the perfect opportunity to try out very simple rules, eg move forwards; if touching red turn right; if touching blue turn left. Seems to work surprisingly well. I like the idea that Scratch could be used to prototype real world robot algorithms.

I started with Scratch Cat rather than a ball, but extremities would "catch" on the colours and lead to twirling and getting stuck.

I said: "I'd like to experiment further with different angles and number of steps. Maybe with a timer to see how fast the ball completes the track. This could be automated to determine the best parameters."

I've started this. Runs are now automated with randomly selected parameters. I need to sort the list on time to create a proper sense of which parameters work best or even better, plot a surface with the 2 parameters to see the "shape" of the parameter space. I also need to add jitter to the start point to see how robust each result is.

Sometimes the robot cheats and returns to the gate by going the wrong way down the track. Maybe need multiple gates to track this?

Oh dear - I said I was going to get an early night tonight...
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Revisiting Day 9

Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

Just run the project and the ball will use simple rules to travel around the uncoloured track. It will run over and over with different speed and angle parameters and store them in 3 lists: time for run, speed and angle. Press s/h to show/hide the lists.

title: Wandering Race for Watermelon
description:
This is a remix of Getting Unstuck #7 Pen patterns Wandering for Watermelon https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236164578/
At a suggestion from a fellow Scratcher's comment, I added a watermelon explosion.

Reflection:  I have enjoyed creating new challenges each day.  I would recommend the 21 days Getting Unstuck challenge to everyone.  The community was great and I would wait for the 7 am email to come to find out what was the challenge.  Early on I would jump right in to create.  Later I would think about the challenge during my day and then code with a plan.

See you at the Scratch Conference!

Using my backpack, I brought in some of their scripts in this version and made some adjustments.  To be honest, I am still not happy with this project, but my time tonight is limited, as I got to pack up and get ready to travel tomorrow for the Scratch@MIT Conference!!!!

title: Unstuck Day 20: Cat Chase revised
description:
This is a basic remix of the game Cheese Chase by John Woodcock from the book Coding Games in Scratch. The first time I made Cheese Chase, it was so difficult! 


When I posted this game for day 9, I only had the dog, the cat and the ghost.  Now, I added the crabs to increase the difficulty.  I also put in the message 'Game Over' to signal the end of the game.  The one thing that I can't seem to get is how to stop the music when the game is completed.
instructions:
Click on the green flag to begin. You will be using the arrow keys to try and navigate the dog to catch the cat.  If the dog touches the blue wall, it will stop.  Every time you touch the cat, you will score 10 points. 
There are a few things that can stop you, though.  If a crab touches the dog, the dog won't be able to move and the game is over.  Also, there is a ghost that will randomly pop up.  If it touches the dog, the game is over.  Have fun!

Enjoy it!

A remix of Challenge #18.

Have so enjoyed this challenge experience.
Being in a different timezone meant it felt like I was always coming late to the party!
I realize I often interpreted the instructions differently to others, sometimes being THAT kid that didn't read instructions carefully!
I loved seeing others creative coding talents and know the future of coding is very excited if our students are being exposed to such brilliant minds.
I look forward to the next set of challenges and to presenting them to students.  Thankyou!

title: water clock
description:
Getting Unstuck day 20
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
I started from a previous project of mine, where I used a pendulum performing a regular motion as the oscillator which gives "tic" to the clock. 
In this revised project I use drops of water dripping from a tap at regular time intervals to generate a "tic" broadcast message than make the needles move.
Each needle when receive the "tic" message rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the drops falling and on the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.
The drop block uses "slide in N seconds" to generate "tic" messages  at regular time intervals.

Credits for images:
www.flaticon.com
Tap by Pixel perfect
Drop & Recipient by Freepik
Clock by Dimitry Miroliubo
instructions:
In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
A regular phenomenon, as the dripping of water from a tap, can be used as source of a regular pulse that make the clock move.
The clock synchronizes with the real time clock when the green flag is pressed (seconds are excluded, so that thin needle always starts at 00).

title: Getting Unstuck 20 - Day 7 update
description:
For this remade project, I decided to incorporate a fair isle pattern into the knitting animation. For now it can only draw a flower, but I would like to have it do a different design each time, either randomly or letting the user choose from a list of designs.

I was a few rows into putting all the stitches into one long script when I realized the top of the design is the bottom in reverse. That made it a lot quicker - I made each row a separate block then did them in reverse after I got to the middle. 

Music is Good Thoughts by Lobo Loco from the Free Music Archive.
instructions:
Click the green flag to fill the screen with knitting. You can press shift while clicking the green flag to run it in turbo mode, which will create the whole pattern very quickly, as the regular mode is pretty slow. This does make the animation of the needles kind of go away though - I wish there was an in-between!

Also sometimes you need to click the green flag twice to get the needles to start moving? Not sure why.

title: Day 20 Getting Unstuck - revision of Day 13
description:
Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

"ceiling fan blue" image from wpclipart.com

Reflect: Why did you choose this project to revisit?
I knew the path the balloon takes when blown could be better modeled by improving the mathematics used to determine the new location. I don't teach geometry or trigonometry so I had to do a little research and some trial and error modeling to figure out if my mathematics was correct so I also used this as a reason to use the Desmos online graphing calculator a little more fully. 
The mathematics required to determine the path the balloon should take when blown by the fan is demonstrated at https://www.desmos.com/calculator/pftuv8rh3f
instructions: Move the fan close to the balloon to blow it around. If you leave the balloon alone for a few seconds, it will change color.  The balloon will return to the center if you blow it off the screen.

title: Unstuck - Day 20
description:
This project is a remix of a previous unstuck challenge.  It is just a variation of a traditional pong game.  We decided to count how many times the ball hits the Scratch Cat. When the score is greater than 10, then the ball moves faster. After 20 and 30 it also gets faster.  

I made these changes: 
Each time the ball goes behind the cat, the score decreases by 5.  When the score is less than 0, the game is over and a Game Over background  appears.
When the speed changes, the ball switched colors (changes costume)
instructions:

Move your mouse up and down and try to hit the ball.
Try to keep up!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - revisit
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 20: choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it.

For this project I revisited an earlier game I made for Day 9 and 18. There was some code that I couldn't get working properly (the food sensing the ant and assigning points based on the costume). I had put a request in the forum and had some good advice. I still couldn't get the code working and gave up. Because the Scratchers giving me advice were ALOT more experienced than I, I figured they must know what they are talking about and the code should work. So I decided to revisit this same project, determined to figure out the code. After looking at it I found the problem (conflicting actions) and was able to make it work, just like they said it should!

I think several things worked:
1) I needed the break from the pervious day to see it all with fresh eyes
2) determination, knowing that the code SHOULD work. Therefore there was a problem somewhere that I needed to find
3) help from others
instructions:
Press the green flag to get started. Your objective is to gather as many food pellets as possible to take to the feeding center.

Use the arrow keys to move the ant through the maze.

Red pellets = kills the ant and stops all action
Yellow/green = +1 point
Purple/pink = -1 point

title: Unstuck Day 20 project copy
description:
I finally figured out one way to get the sprite to follow the mouse x coordinate only when I want to: I used boolean operators to permit the sprite to move only if the cursor is within a certain y coordinate value. I'm sure there are other ways to do this, but this one works and I was happy to add it to the project.

The new problem I had was assigning notes to the values of the x axis. I tried unsuccessfully to come up with a formula to solve it for me, so I ended up using lots of "if x is greater than m and less than n, then play note p" which was tedious, but hey, it works!

Unstuck Challenge Day 3 remixed for Day 20 #CreativeComputing
instructions:
Drag the Scratch cats along the black lines to change the note!

The bottom line plays low notes, the middle line plays notes in the middle, and the top line plays high notes.

Press "play chord" to hear all 3 notes (low, middle, and high) together!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20
description:
Made for the Getting Unstuck Day 20 activity which was to revisit an earlier project. In this case it was the one I did for day 2.
For this revision I added a slider so that the user can choose the line width of the flower. I also added a random element for the size of the flower.

Notes for the original, Day 2 project.
Inspired by Seymour Papert and Turtle Logo I thought I would use the pen tools and draw things that are a bit like crystal flowers. When doing any Logo I'm always reminded of a photo in the MIT museum of Seymour with one of the big early turtles.

I started with drawing the flowers in a random place but this felt a little strange so I changed it to draw at the mouse pointer to give the user more control. The random block is still there though, if you want to give it a try.
The next thing I'd like to do is let the user choose a colour from a palette. Maybe choose the line thickness as well.
instructions:

Click anywhere on the background to draw a flower.

title: Color Mix copy getting Unstuck 19
description:
An interactive project to teach color mixing to children. Many of them don't know what happens when mixing colors. This can be followed by an art project using real paints!
Use of Cloning and sensing blocks- week 4 activity - CCOW
I finally finished this project that I ad begun one year before. I'd like to make different combinations of colors each time/each level but only now I  solved the problem. H
instructions:
Click on the green flag to start, and each time you want to add color.
Wait until the last drop is fallen before clicking the next color.

title: Crash and jump (Getting Unstuck #20)
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge #20 - "First, create a studio and add all of your Getting Unstuck projects to it. Second, choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it. What's something about the project that would benefit from more time or fresh eyes? ".

My original version of this (for activity#5) used glide for all the movement of both the rocket and the alien. I saw some great examples of how to "jump" in other people's work so updated the alien jump based on that. 

Other future enhancements:
- change rocket flight (it is still basic).
- fix the fact sprite is upside down after bouncing off edge
- fix odd higher jump when bouncing off side (might be due to costume area?)
instructions: Press SPACE to lift off and watch how things go.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 20
description:
The Getting Unstuck Challenge for day 20 was to copy and revise a previous day's project.  I chose my project from day 9, which was to create a project that uses the "touching color" block.  It was originally just the first backdrop, so I extended it to two maze screens and added the variable to keep track of how many times Scratch hits the wall (touches black).

My new version now  also includes challenges from several of the previous days!

Day 19 - Use the "create a clone" block
Day 14 - Use the "join" block
Day 12 - Have 3 separate scenes
Day 8 - Create a variable to keep track of the number of times something happens
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Getting Unstuck Challenge for day 9 was: "Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game."
instructions:
Click the green arrow to start the maze.

Use the arrow keys to guide Scratch the Cat through the maze.  If you touch any of the walls Scratch will turn around and move back.

Click the green arrow to start over.
